<ce:section-title>Graphical abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para view="all">Two supramolecular nickel-organic frameworks, [Ni(HBTC)(bix)]<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>) and [Ni<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(BTC)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(<ce:italic>m</ce:italic>bix)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>]<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>6<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>) (bix<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1,4-bis(imidazole-l-yl-methyl)benzene, <ce:italic>m</ce:italic>bix<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1,3-bis(imidazole-l-yl-methyl)benzene, and H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>BTC<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylate), were obtained under hydrothermal reactions. The 3D supramolecular structure of compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> exhibits a rarely encountered 3D (4, 6)-connected <ce:bold>fsc</ce:bold> topological net when hydrogen-bonging interactions between the adjacent layers are taken into account. Compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> manifests an unprecedented 2D (3, 4)-connected topological net. Close <ce:italic>π</ce:italic>⋯<ce:italic>π</ce:italic> stacking interactions occur between the adjacent layers of compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>. The magnetic studies show that compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> features overall ferromagnetic property. Whereas compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> was treated as a mononuclear model, which presents strong zero-field splitting (ZFS). Furthermore, the IR and TGA properties of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> were also studied.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Graphical abstract

Two supramolecular nickel-organic frameworks, [Ni(HBTC)(bix)] n  (1) and [Ni3(BTC)2(mbix)3(H2O)4] n  ⋅6nH2O (2) (bix=1,4-bis(imidazole-l-yl-methyl)benzene, mbix=1,3-bis(imidazole-l-yl-methyl)benzene, and H3BTC=1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylate), were obtained under hydrothermal reactions. The 3D supramolecular structure of compound 1 exhibits a rarely encountered 3D (4, 6)-connected fsc topological net when hydrogen-bonging interactions between the adjacent layers are taken into account. Compound 2 manifests an unprecedented 2D (3, 4)-connected topological net. Close π⋯π stacking interactions occur between the adjacent layers of compound 2. The magnetic studies show that compound 1 features overall ferromagnetic property. Whereas compound 2 was treated as a mononuclear model, which presents strong zero-field splitting (ZFS). Furthermore, the IR and TGA properties of 1 and 2 were also studied.

elements.clean_text:
Abstract

Two supramolecular nickel-organic frameworks, [Ni(HBTC)(bix)] n  (1) and [Ni3(BTC)2(mbix)3(H2O)4] n  ⋅6nH2O (2) (bix=1,4-bis(imidazole-l-yl-methyl)benzene, mbix=1,3-bis(imidazole-l-yl-methyl)benzene, and H3BTC=1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylate), have been hydrothermally prepared by the assembly of H3BTC, Ni2+ with bix or mbix. Compound 1 shows a 2D layer structure, whose 3D supramolecular structure exhibits a fsc topology when hydrogen-bonging interactions between the adjacent layers are taken into account. Compound 2 manifests an unprecedented 2D (3, 4)-connected topological net. The 3D supramolecular framework of 2 is formed through π⋯π stacking interactions between the adjacent layers. The magnetic studies show that 1 features overall ferromagnetic property whilst 2 presents strong zero-field splitting (ZFS) when treated as a mononuclear model. Furthermore, the IR and TGA properties of 1 and 2 were also studied.

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">The design and synthesis of functional metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) have been received extensive attention in recent years owing to their potential as functional materials  and intriguing topologies . Consequently, a variety of coordination polymers with complicated architectures and topologies have been synthesized successfully . It is widely acknowledged that the coordinative bonding is normally considered to be the primary interaction to sustain the network, while those supramolecular interactions, such as hydrogen-bonding, π⋯π stacking interactions and metal–metal interactions are also expected to control the assembly and dimensionality of the resulting structures and direct the overall supramolecular topology . The topological analysis could be a better insight into the supramolecular architectures. Upon topological analysis, complicated metal-organic frameworks can be reduced to simple equivalent networks .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The design and synthesis of functional metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) have been received extensive attention in recent years owing to their potential as functional materials  and intriguing topologies . Consequently, a variety of coordination polymers with complicated architectures and topologies have been synthesized successfully . It is widely acknowledged that the coordinative bonding is normally considered to be the primary interaction to sustain the network, while those supramolecular interactions, such as hydrogen-bonding, π⋯π stacking interactions and metal-metal interactions are also expected to control the assembly and dimensionality of the resulting structures and direct the overall supramolecular topology . The topological analysis could be a better insight into the supramolecular architectures. Upon topological analysis, complicated metal-organic frameworks can be reduced to simple equivalent networks .

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">According to our investigation, MOFs with 3-, 4-, or 6-connected topologies in which <ce:italic>d</ce:italic>-block metal ions are used as nodes are commonly observed . However, the 3D frameworks with mixed connectivity, such as (3, 6)-, (4, 6)-, and (4, 8)-connected frameworks, are considered to be difficult to achieve because of their greater geometric limitations . Our interests are focused on designing metal-organic frameworks using transition metal ions to assembly with mixed-ligands of polycarboxylates and flexible <ce:italic>N</ce:italic>-donor ligands and carrying out their topological analyses. In our knowledge, MOFs constructed from aromatic carboxylates and bix (bix<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1,4-bis(imidazole-l-yl-methyl)benzene) or <ce:italic>m</ce:italic>bix (<ce:italic>m</ce:italic>bix<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1,3-bis(imidazole-l-yl-methyl)benzene) have not been well explored . Recently, we have successfully obtained five novel d<ce:sup loc="post">10</ce:sup> metal-organic coordination polymers containing mixed ligands of polycarboxylates and bix (or <ce:italic>m</ce:italic>bix). These polymers exhibit different topologies from one to another, in which the polycarboxylate acids display their characteristic distinct coordination modes . As part of our ongoing effort in the design of topological architecture, we have investigated the assemblies of Ni ion and the mixed-ligands of H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>BTC (H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>BTC<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylate) and bix (or <ce:italic>m</ce:italic>bix), which led to the isolation of two 3D supramolecular MOFs, [Ni(HBTC)(bix)]<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>) and [Ni<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(BTC)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(<ce:italic>m</ce:italic>bix)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>]<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>6<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>). The crystal structures, topological analyses, thermal stability of these compounds, along with their magnetic properties will be represented and discussed in this paper.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: According to our investigation, MOFs with 3-, 4-, or 6-connected topologies in which d-block metal ions are used as nodes are commonly observed . However, the 3D frameworks with mixed connectivity, such as (3, 6)-, (4, 6)-, and (4, 8)-connected frameworks, are considered to be difficult to achieve because of their greater geometric limitations . Our interests are focused on designing metal-organic frameworks using transition metal ions to assembly with mixed-ligands of polycarboxylates and flexible N-donor ligands and carrying out their topological analyses. In our knowledge, MOFs constructed from aromatic carboxylates and bix (bix=1,4-bis(imidazole-l-yl-methyl)benzene) or mbix (mbix=1,3-bis(imidazole-l-yl-methyl)benzene) have not been well explored . Recently, we have successfully obtained five novel d10 metal-organic coordination polymers containing mixed ligands of polycarboxylates and bix (or mbix). These polymers exhibit different topologies from one to another, in which the polycarboxylate acids display their characteristic distinct coordination modes . As part of our ongoing effort in the design of topological architecture, we have investigated the assemblies of Ni ion and the mixed-ligands of H3BTC (H3BTC=1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylate) and bix (or mbix), which led to the isolation of two 3D supramolecular MOFs, [Ni(HBTC)(bix)] n  (1) and [Ni3(BTC)2(mbix)3(H2O)4] n  ⋅6nH2O (2). The crystal structures, topological analyses, thermal stability of these compounds, along with their magnetic properties will be represented and discussed in this paper.

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">Bix and <ce:italic>m</ce:italic>bix were synthesized by the literature method . All the other chemicals were commercially available and used as purchased. NiCl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>6H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (0.125<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol, 29.7<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg), H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>BTC (0.125<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol, 26.3<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg), bix (0.25<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol, 59.5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg), and H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL) were placed in a Teflon-lined stainless steel vessel and the mixture was sealed and heated to 130<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C for 72<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h. The reaction system was cooled to room temperature during 36<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h. Green prism crystals of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> were obtained, yield: 39<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg, 62% based on NiCl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>6H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O. Blue prism crystals of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> were obtained in a similar way as for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> except that <ce:italic>m</ce:italic>bix was employed instead of bix and the reaction temperature was 160<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, yield: 29.8<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg, 48% based on NiCl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>6H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O. <ce:italic>Elemental analysis</ce:italic> (%) Anal. Calc. For compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> (C<ce:inf loc="post">23</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">18</ce:inf>NiN<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>): Calcd. C 54.69, H 3.59, N 11.09; Found: C 54.67, H 3.18, N 11.15(%) and for compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> (C<ce:inf loc="post">60</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">68</ce:inf>Ni<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>N<ce:inf loc="post">12</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">22</ce:inf>): Calcd. C 48.52, H 4.61, N 11.32; Found: C 48.91, H 4.58, N 11.36(%). Empirical absorption corrections were applied to the data using the CrystalClear program . The structures of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> were solved by the direct method and refined by the full-matrix least-squares on <ce:italic>F</ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup> using the SHELXTL-97 program . All of the non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. The hydrogen atoms of organic ligands in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> were treated by geometrical positions or located from difference Fourier maps. The hydrogen atoms of lattice and coordinated water molecules in <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> were not added. Crystallographic data and structural refinements for compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> are summarized in Table S1. The selected bond distances and bond angles for compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> are summarized in Table S2 and Table S3, respectively. The IR spectra of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> () and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> () show the characteristic bands of the carboxylic groups in the usual region at 1457–1343<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> for the symmetric vibrations and at 1630–1535<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> for the asymmetric vibrations. The presence of the characteristic band attributed to the protonated carboxylic group is observed at 1720<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, indicating the incomplete deprotonation of the H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>BTC ligand.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Bix and mbix were synthesized by the literature method . All the other chemicals were commercially available and used as purchased. NiCl2 ⋅6H2O (0.125mmol, 29.7mg), H3BTC (0.125mmol, 26.3mg), bix (0.25mmol, 59.5mg), and H2O (10mL) were placed in a Teflon-lined stainless steel vessel and the mixture was sealed and heated to 130°C for 72h. The reaction system was cooled to room temperature during 36h. Green prism crystals of 1 were obtained, yield: 39mg, 62% based on NiCl2 ⋅6H2O. Blue prism crystals of 2 were obtained in a similar way as for 1 except that mbix was employed instead of bix and the reaction temperature was 160°C, yield: 29.8mg, 48% based on NiCl2 ⋅6H2O. Elemental analysis (%) Anal. Calc. For compound 1 (C23H18NiN4O6): Calcd. C 54.69, H 3.59, N 11.09; Found: C 54.67, H 3.18, N 11.15(%) and for compound 2 (C60H68Ni3N12O22): Calcd. C 48.52, H 4.61, N 11.32; Found: C 48.91, H 4.58, N 11.36(%). Empirical absorption corrections were applied to the data using the CrystalClear program . The structures of 1 and 2 were solved by the direct method and refined by the full-matrix least-squares on F 2 using the SHELXTL-97 program . All of the non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. The hydrogen atoms of organic ligands in 1 and 2 were treated by geometrical positions or located from difference Fourier maps. The hydrogen atoms of lattice and coordinated water molecules in 2 were not added. Crystallographic data and structural refinements for compounds 1 and 2 are summarized in Table S1. The selected bond distances and bond angles for compound 1 and 2 are summarized in Table S2 and Table S3, respectively. The IR spectra of 1 () and 2 () show the characteristic bands of the carboxylic groups in the usual region at 1457-1343cm-1 for the symmetric vibrations and at 1630-1535cm-1 for the asymmetric vibrations. The presence of the characteristic band attributed to the protonated carboxylic group is observed at 1720cm-1 for 1, indicating the incomplete deprotonation of the H3BTC ligand.

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">Compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> crystallizes in the triclinic space group <ce:italic>P–</ce:italic>1 and the asymmetric unit contains one Ni ion, one bix and one HBTC<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> anion. There exists one carboxyl group in the HBTC<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> anion. As shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig1"></ce:float-anchor>a, the Ni1 centre is in a distorted octahedral coordination geometry, and is coordinated by two nitrogen atoms from two distinct bix ligands (N1, N4B), two carboxylate oxygen atoms in a bidentate mode from two symmetry-related HBTC<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> ligands (O3A, O4C) and one chelating carboxylate oxygen atoms (O5, O6) from another HBTC<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> ligand. The Ni–O/N bond lengths are all in the normal range . The bond angles around Ni1 centre range from 60.71(4) to 169.65(6)°. The two nitrogen atoms occupy the axial positions of the octahedron with the N1–Ni1–N4B bond angle of 169.65(6)°, whereas the equatorial plane of the distorted octahedral sphere is defined by the four carboxylate oxygen atoms. The Ni1 center is approximately coplanar with the mean plane of the four equatorial oxygen atoms with a deviation of 0.0191<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å 
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig4"></ce:float-anchor>.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Compound 1 crystallizes in the triclinic space group P-1 and the asymmetric unit contains one Ni ion, one bix and one HBTC2- anion. There exists one carboxyl group in the HBTC2- anion. As shown in  a, the Ni1 centre is in a distorted octahedral coordination geometry, and is coordinated by two nitrogen atoms from two distinct bix ligands (N1, N4B), two carboxylate oxygen atoms in a bidentate mode from two symmetry-related HBTC2- ligands (O3A, O4C) and one chelating carboxylate oxygen atoms (O5, O6) from another HBTC2- ligand. The Ni-O/N bond lengths are all in the normal range . The bond angles around Ni1 centre range from 60.71(4) to 169.65(6)°. The two nitrogen atoms occupy the axial positions of the octahedron with the N1-Ni1-N4B bond angle of 169.65(6)°, whereas the equatorial plane of the distorted octahedral sphere is defined by the four carboxylate oxygen atoms. The Ni1 center is approximately coplanar with the mean plane of the four equatorial oxygen atoms with a deviation of 0.0191Å  .

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">The HBTC<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> ligand employs one chelating carboxylate group and one bidentate carboxylate group, adopting a (<ce:italic>k</ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>)-(<ce:italic>k</ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>-<ce:italic>k</ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>)-<ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> coordination mode (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig5"></ce:float-anchor>a), to connect the Ni ions into a 1D double chain motif with alternating 8-membered (A) and 16-membered (B) rings (), which are common arrangements found in other transition metal carboxylate complexes . The distance of the two Ni atoms in A ring is 4.4950(5)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å. The flexible bix ligands bridge the metal centres of the 1D double chains in an <ce:italic>anti</ce:italic>-conformation to build up a 2D layer (). The dihedral angle between two terminal imidazole rings is 43.79°. Finally, these 2D layers are further extended into a 3D supramolecular architecture with channels through strong hydrogen bonds involving the uncoordinated carboxylate group and the chelating carboxylate group [O1–H0⋯O5#1 2.706<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å; symmetry code: (#1) –<ce:italic>x</ce:italic>, –<ce:italic>y</ce:italic>, 1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>–<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:italic>z</ce:italic>], as illustrated in .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The HBTC2- ligand employs one chelating carboxylate group and one bidentate carboxylate group, adopting a (k 2)-(k 1-k 1)-μ 3 coordination mode ( a), to connect the Ni ions into a 1D double chain motif with alternating 8-membered (A) and 16-membered (B) rings (), which are common arrangements found in other transition metal carboxylate complexes . The distance of the two Ni atoms in A ring is 4.4950(5)Å. The flexible bix ligands bridge the metal centres of the 1D double chains in an anti-conformation to build up a 2D layer (). The dihedral angle between two terminal imidazole rings is 43.79°. Finally, these 2D layers are further extended into a 3D supramolecular architecture with channels through strong hydrogen bonds involving the uncoordinated carboxylate group and the chelating carboxylate group [O1-H0⋯O5#1 2.706Å; symmetry code: (#1) -x, -y, 1- z], as illustrated in .

elements.clean_text: From the topological point of view, the 2D layer in 1 is a (3, 5)-connected net. The long connection is corresponding to a bix bridge. Each Ni1 atom acts as a five-connected node and every HBTC2- ligand functions as a 3-connected node in the ratio 1:1 (b). The 2D net is analyzed by OLEX program  and the result shows that the Schläfli symbol can be described as (42 ⋅6)(42 ⋅67 ⋅8). The vertex symbol of the 3-connected node and the five-connected node in this 2D net is 4⋅4⋅62 and 4⋅4⋅64 ⋅64 ⋅63 ⋅63 ⋅63 ⋅63 ⋅∗⋅∗, respectively. To the best of our knowledge, there is only one example of 2D topological net with Schläfli symbol of (42 ⋅6)(42 ⋅67 ⋅8) reported to date . If the hydrogen-bonding interactions are taken into account , the HBTC2- ligand can be regarded as a 4-connected node. Therefore, the connectivity of 1 can be simplified as a (4, 6)-connected 3D network and the overall Schläfli symbol becomes (44 ⋅62)(44 ⋅610 ⋅8) (c). The 4-connected node and 6-connected node of this 3D net can be further specified by the vertex symbol of 4⋅4⋅4⋅4⋅62 ⋅62 and 4⋅4⋅4⋅4⋅65 ⋅65 ⋅65 ⋅65 ⋅65 ⋅65 ⋅65 ⋅65 ⋅∗⋅∗⋅∗, respectively. According to O'Keeffe, this net with Schläfli symbol (44 ⋅62)(44 ⋅610 ⋅8) is named as fsc net . The coordination sequences of this fsc net are 4, 16, 38, 66, 102, 146, 198, 258, 326, 402 for the 4-connected node and 4, 18, 38, 66, 102, 146, 198, 258, 326, 402 for the 6-connected node . As far as we know, metal-organic frameworks with the fsc topology have been rarely encountered .

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">The asymmetric unit of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> contains four crystallographically independent Ni atoms, two kinds of unique BTC<ce:sup loc="post">3−</ce:sup> ligands, three kinds of unique <ce:italic>m</ce:italic>bix ligands, and four coordinated water molecules and six lattice water molecules. All the Ni atoms are six-coordinated. The Ni1 (or Ni3) is coordinated by three carboxylate oxygen atoms from two BTC<ce:sup loc="post">3−</ce:sup>, two nitrogen atoms from two <ce:italic>m</ce:italic>bix ligands and a water molecule. In the distorted octahedral sphere of Ni1 and Ni3 centres, the four oxygen atoms make up of the equatorial plane, whereas the two nitrogen atoms locate at the axial positions of the octahedron. The bond angles of N1–Ni1–N4B and N9–Ni3–N12D are 178.22(9) and 176.84(9)°, respectively (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig2"></ce:float-anchor>a). The Ni1 and Ni3 centres are approximately coplanar with the mean plane of their four equatorial oxygen atoms with a deviation of 0.0572 and 0.0359<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, respectively. As for Ni2 and Ni4 centres, they are both surrounded by one monodentate carboxylate oxygen atom from BTC<ce:sup loc="post">3−</ce:sup>, one nitrogen atom from <ce:italic>m</ce:italic>bix and one water molecule along with their corresponding symmetry-related atoms (a). The arrangement sequences of the coordination atoms around Ni2 and Ni4 are similar to that of Ni1 and Ni3. All the coordination bonds are in normal distances .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The asymmetric unit of 2 contains four crystallographically independent Ni atoms, two kinds of unique BTC3- ligands, three kinds of unique mbix ligands, and four coordinated water molecules and six lattice water molecules. All the Ni atoms are six-coordinated. The Ni1 (or Ni3) is coordinated by three carboxylate oxygen atoms from two BTC3-, two nitrogen atoms from two mbix ligands and a water molecule. In the distorted octahedral sphere of Ni1 and Ni3 centres, the four oxygen atoms make up of the equatorial plane, whereas the two nitrogen atoms locate at the axial positions of the octahedron. The bond angles of N1-Ni1-N4B and N9-Ni3-N12D are 178.22(9) and 176.84(9)°, respectively ( a). The Ni1 and Ni3 centres are approximately coplanar with the mean plane of their four equatorial oxygen atoms with a deviation of 0.0572 and 0.0359Å, respectively. As for Ni2 and Ni4 centres, they are both surrounded by one monodentate carboxylate oxygen atom from BTC3-, one nitrogen atom from mbix and one water molecule along with their corresponding symmetry-related atoms (a). The arrangement sequences of the coordination atoms around Ni2 and Ni4 are similar to that of Ni1 and Ni3. All the coordination bonds are in normal distances .

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">Each BTC<ce:sup loc="post">3−</ce:sup> ligand utilizes one chelating carboxylate group and two monodentate carboxylate groups, adopting a (<ce:italic>k</ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>)-(<ce:italic>k</ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>)-(<ce:italic>k</ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>)-<ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> coordination mode (b), to join the Ni ions into a 1D ladder structure (). Three crystallographically distinct <ce:italic>m</ce:italic>bix ligands in <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> all adopt a <ce:italic>syn</ce:italic>-conformation with the dihedral angles between two terminal imidazole rings varying from 19.465° to 81.161°. The Ni2 and Ni4 along with their corresponding symmetry-related atoms are linked by a <ce:italic>m</ce:italic>bix ligand to form an infinite zigzag chain with the distance of Ni2⋯Ni4 being 10.1750(2)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å. The other two <ce:italic>m</ce:italic>bix ligands each form a 24-membered ring via coordination to Ni1 or Ni3 with the distances of Ni1⋯Ni1B and Ni3⋯Ni3D being 8.2014(6) and 7.9828(5)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, respectively (). The zigzag chains pass through the centres of the 1D ladders, which are further extended by the 24-membered rings to produce a 2D layer structure (b). Close <ce:italic>π</ce:italic>⋯<ce:italic>π</ce:italic> contacts occur between aromatic rings of BTC<ce:sup loc="post">3−</ce:sup> and the phenyl rings of <ce:italic>m</ce:italic>bix ligands of the adjacent layers with face-to-face distance of 3.6519<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å (with centroid-to-centroid distance of 3.935<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å). Thus, the structure of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> can also be described as a 3D supramolecular network (). If the <ce:italic>m</ce:italic>bix ligands are considered as connectors, and both crystallographically independent BTC<ce:sup loc="post">3−</ce:sup> ligands are simplified as 3-connected nodes, there exist two kinds of 3-connected nodes (Ni1/Ni3 and BTC<ce:sup loc="post">3−</ce:sup>) and one kind of 4-connected node (Ni2/Ni4). The topology of this 2D network can be described as a (3, 4)-connected net (c). Therefore, the Schläfli symbol of this net is (5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>6<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>)(5<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>6)(5<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>8<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>). To the best of our knowledge, the 2D metal-organic frameworks with this topology net are previously unknown.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Each BTC3- ligand utilizes one chelating carboxylate group and two monodentate carboxylate groups, adopting a (k 2)-(k 1)-(k 1)-μ 3 coordination mode (b), to join the Ni ions into a 1D ladder structure (). Three crystallographically distinct mbix ligands in 2 all adopt a syn-conformation with the dihedral angles between two terminal imidazole rings varying from 19.465° to 81.161°. The Ni2 and Ni4 along with their corresponding symmetry-related atoms are linked by a mbix ligand to form an infinite zigzag chain with the distance of Ni2⋯Ni4 being 10.1750(2)Å. The other two mbix ligands each form a 24-membered ring via coordination to Ni1 or Ni3 with the distances of Ni1⋯Ni1B and Ni3⋯Ni3D being 8.2014(6) and 7.9828(5)Å, respectively (). The zigzag chains pass through the centres of the 1D ladders, which are further extended by the 24-membered rings to produce a 2D layer structure (b). Close π⋯π contacts occur between aromatic rings of BTC3- and the phenyl rings of mbix ligands of the adjacent layers with face-to-face distance of 3.6519Å (with centroid-to-centroid distance of 3.935Å). Thus, the structure of 2 can also be described as a 3D supramolecular network (). If the mbix ligands are considered as connectors, and both crystallographically independent BTC3- ligands are simplified as 3-connected nodes, there exist two kinds of 3-connected nodes (Ni1/Ni3 and BTC3-) and one kind of 4-connected node (Ni2/Ni4). The topology of this 2D network can be described as a (3, 4)-connected net (c). Therefore, the Schläfli symbol of this net is (5⋅62)(52 ⋅6)(54 ⋅82). To the best of our knowledge, the 2D metal-organic frameworks with this topology net are previously unknown.

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">In comparison, when different symmetries of flexible imidazole-based ligands (bix and <ce:italic>m</ce:italic>bix) were employed as coligands to construct <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, absolutely distinct frameworks and topologies are emerged in these metal-organic frameworks. In <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, twofold deprotonated HBTC<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> ligand employs two carboxylate groups, adopting a (<ce:italic>k</ce:italic>

<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>-<ce:italic>k</ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>)-<ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> coordination mode (a). Whereas in <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, the coordination mode of triply deprotonated BTC<ce:sup loc="post">3−</ce:sup> ligand is (<ce:italic>k</ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>)-(<ce:italic>k</ce:italic>

elements.clean_text: In comparison, when different symmetries of flexible imidazole-based ligands (bix and mbix) were employed as coligands to construct 1 and 2, absolutely distinct frameworks and topologies are emerged in these metal-organic frameworks. In 1, twofold deprotonated HBTC2- ligand employs two carboxylate groups, adopting a (k 2)-(k 1-k 1)-μ 3 coordination mode (a). Whereas in 2, the coordination mode of triply deprotonated BTC3- ligand is (k 2)-(k 1)-(k 1)-μ 3 (b), utilizing all the three carboxylate groups.

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">The thermal stability of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> was examined by TGA in a nitrogen atmosphere. The TGA curve of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> () indicates that there is no significant loss up to about 370<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C. The TGA curve of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> () reveals a weight loss of 7.31% from room temperature to 134<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, which can be assigned to the weight loss of the lattice water molecules (calcd<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>7.27%). The subsequent weight loss of 4.76% from 134<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C to 343<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C can be attributed to the weight loss of the coordinated water molecules (calcd<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>4.85%). And from 343<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C the decomposition of the framework of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> starts.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The thermal stability of 1 and 2 was examined by TGA in a nitrogen atmosphere. The TGA curve of 1 () indicates that there is no significant loss up to about 370°C. The TGA curve of 2 () reveals a weight loss of 7.31% from room temperature to 134°C, which can be assigned to the weight loss of the lattice water molecules (calcd=7.27%). The subsequent weight loss of 4.76% from 134°C to 343°C can be attributed to the weight loss of the coordinated water molecules (calcd=4.85%). And from 343°C the decomposition of the framework of 2 starts.

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">The temperature-dependent magnetic susceptibility data of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> have been measured for polycrystalline samples at an applied magnetic field of 10 kOe in the temperature range of 2–300<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K, as shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig3"></ce:float-anchor>. For <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, <ce:italic>χ<ce:inf loc="post">m</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> is the molar magnetic susceptibility for per Ni<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> unit (A ring in ). The experimental <ce:italic>χ<ce:inf loc="post">m</ce:inf>T</ce:italic> value at room temperature is 2.45<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mol<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K, which is as expected for two magnetically quasi-isolated <ce:italic>S</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1 ions (<ce:italic>g</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>><ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2.00). Upon cooling, the <ce:italic>χ<ce:inf loc="post">m</ce:inf>T</ce:italic> value increases to a maximum of 3.12<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mol<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K at 5.55<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K, following with a sharp decrease to 2.56<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mol<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>

elements.clean_text: The temperature-dependent magnetic susceptibility data of 1 and 2 have been measured for polycrystalline samples at an applied magnetic field of 10 kOe in the temperature range of 2-300K, as shown in  . For 1, χm  is the molar magnetic susceptibility for per Ni2 unit (A ring in ). The experimental χmT value at room temperature is 2.45cm3 mol-1 K, which is as expected for two magnetically quasi-isolated S =1 ions (g >2.00). Upon cooling, the χmT value increases to a maximum of 3.12cm3 mol-1 K at 5.55K, following with a sharp decrease to 2.56cm3 mol-1 K at 2K, suggesting an overall ferromagnetic interaction. Fitting all data to the Curie-Weiss law gave Weiss constant of θ =3.42K (), also indicative of ferromagnetic exchange interactions. With the consideration of the intermolecular exchange interaction (ZJ') in the molecular-field approximation, the magnetic analysis was carried out by using the spin Hamiltonian   H = - 2   JS   1     S   2   - D (   S   1   2   +   S   2   2   )  , where J is the intramolecular exchange integral, D the zero-field splitting parameter. And the expression of magnetic susceptibility reported in the literature can be used to fit the data . A good fit was achieved with the fitting parameters as follows: g =2.204, J  = +2.70cm-1, D =-0.035cm-1, ZJ'=-0.133cm-1 and the agreement factor R =Σ[(χmT)obsd -(χmT)calcd]2/Σ(χmT)2 obsd is 1.28×10-4.

elements.clean_text: For 2, the experimental χmT value for per Ni ion at room temperature is 1.11cm3 mol-1 K and increase slowly to a maximum of 1.16cm3 mol-1 K at 22.5K. Below 22.5K, there is a clear decrease to approximately 0.53cm3 mol-1 K at 2K. Although the structure of 2 is two-dimensional, from the magnetic point of view, it can be analyzed with a mononuclear model owing to the long Ni⋯Ni distances between the organic linkers. The resulting magnetic susceptibility is given by Eq. , where θ represents all the weak interactions and the other symbols have their usual meanings. The best fitting gave the parameters g =2.12, D =12.67K, θ =0.747K-1 and the agreement factor R =Σ[(χmT)obsd -(χmT)calcd]2/Σ(χmT)2 obsd is 1.3×10-4. The decrease of χmT value below 22.5K might be mainly attributed to the presence of zero-field splitting (ZFS). elements.content: <ce:para view="all">In summary, we have successfully obtained two nickel-organic frameworks using mixed-ligand of H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>BTC and bix (or <ce:italic>m</ce:italic>bix) under hydrothermal conditions. Compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> both exhibit a 3D supramolecular network with a novel topology formed by hydrogen-bonging interactions or <ce:italic>π</ce:italic>⋯<ce:italic>π</ce:italic> stacking interactions. The different symmetries of bix and <ce:italic>m</ce:italic>bix play an important role in tuning the formation of the network structures of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>. The magnetic study shows that <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> exhibits an overall ferromagnetic interaction between the Ni<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> ions whereas <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> presents strong zero-field splitting (ZFS) based on the magnetic analysis result.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In summary, we have successfully obtained two nickel-organic frameworks using mixed-ligand of H3BTC and bix (or mbix) under hydrothermal conditions. Compounds 1 and 2 both exhibit a 3D supramolecular network with a novel topology formed by hydrogen-bonging interactions or π⋯π stacking interactions. The different symmetries of bix and mbix play an important role in tuning the formation of the network structures of 1 and 2. The magnetic study shows that 1 exhibits an overall ferromagnetic interaction between the Ni2+ ions whereas 2 presents strong zero-field splitting (ZFS) based on the magnetic analysis result.

<ce:para view="all">Bix and <ce:italic>m</ce:italic>bix were synthesized by the literature method . All the other chemicals were commercially available and used as purchased. NiCl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>6H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (0.125<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol, 29.7<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg), H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>BTC (0.125<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol, 26.3<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg), bix (0.25<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol, 59.5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg), and H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL) were placed in a Teflon-lined stainless steel vessel and the mixture was sealed and heated to 130<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C for 72<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h. The reaction system was cooled to room temperature during 36<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h. Green prism crystals of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> were obtained, yield: 39<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg, 62% based on NiCl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>6H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O. Blue prism crystals of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> were obtained in a similar way as for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> except that <ce:italic>m</ce:italic>bix was employed instead of bix and the reaction temperature was 160<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, yield: 29.8<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg, 48% based on NiCl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>6H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O. <ce:italic>Elemental analysis</ce:italic> (%) Anal. Calc. For compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> (C<ce:inf loc="post">23</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">18</ce:inf>NiN<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>): Calcd. C 54.69, H 3.59, N 11.09; Found: C 54.67, H 3.18, N 11.15(%) and for compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> (C<ce:inf loc="post">60</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">68</ce:inf>Ni<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>N<ce:inf loc="post">12</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">22</ce:inf>): Calcd. C 48.52, H 4.61, N 11.32; Found: C 48.91, H 4.58, N 11.36(%). Empirical absorption corrections were applied to the data using the CrystalClear program . The structures of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> were solved by the direct method and refined by the full-matrix least-squares on <ce:italic>F</ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup> using the SHELXTL-97 program . All of the non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. The hydrogen atoms of organic ligands in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> were treated by geometrical positions or located from difference Fourier maps. The hydrogen atoms of lattice and coordinated water molecules in <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> were not added. Crystallographic data and structural refinements for compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> are summarized in Table S1. The selected bond distances and bond angles for compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> are summarized in Table S2 and Table S3, respectively. The IR spectra of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> () and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> () show the characteristic bands of the carboxylic groups in the usual region at 1457–1343<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> for the symmetric vibrations and at 1630–1535<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> for the asymmetric vibrations. The presence of the characteristic band attributed to the protonated carboxylic group is observed at 1720<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, indicating the incomplete deprotonation of the H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>BTC ligand.</ce:para>
cln_elements.clean_text: Bix and mbix were synthesized by the literature method . All the other chemicals were commercially available and used as purchased. NiCl2 ⋅6H2O (0.125mmol, 29.7mg), H3BTC (0.125mmol, 26.3mg), bix (0.25mmol, 59.5mg), and H2O (10mL) were placed in a Teflon-lined stainless steel vessel and the mixture was sealed and heated to 130°C for 72h. The reaction system was cooled to room temperature during 36h. Green prism crystals of 1 were obtained, yield: 39mg, 62% based on NiCl2 ⋅6H2O. Blue prism crystals of 2 were obtained in a similar way as for 1 except that mbix was employed instead of bix and the reaction temperature was 160°C, yield: 29.8mg, 48% based on NiCl2 ⋅6H2O. Elemental analysis (%) Anal. Calc. For compound 1 (C23H18NiN4O6): Calcd. C 54.69, H 3.59, N 11.09; Found: C 54.67, H 3.18, N 11.15(%) and for compound 2 (C60H68Ni3N12O22): Calcd. C 48.52, H 4.61, N 11.32; Found: C 48.91, H 4.58, N 11.36(%). Empirical absorption corrections were applied to the data using the CrystalClear program . The structures of 1 and 2 were solved by the direct method and refined by the full-matrix least-squares on F 2 using the SHELXTL-97 program . All of the non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. The hydrogen atoms of organic ligands in 1 and 2 were treated by geometrical positions or located from difference Fourier maps. The hydrogen atoms of lattice and coordinated water molecules in 2 were not added. Crystallographic data and structural refinements for compounds 1 and 2 are summarized in Table S1. The selected bond distances and bond angles for compound 1 and 2 are summarized in Table S2 and Table S3, respectively. The IR spectra of 1 () and 2 () show the characteristic bands of the carboxylic groups in the usual region at 1457-1343cm-1 for the symmetric vibrations and at 1630-1535cm-1 for the asymmetric vibrations. The presence of the characteristic band attributed to the protonated carboxylic group is observed at 1720cm-1 for 1, indicating the incomplete deprotonation of the H3BTC ligand.

cln_elements.clean_text:
The thermal stability of 1 and 2 was examined by TGA in a nitrogen atmosphere. The TGA curve of 1 () indicates that there is no significant loss up to about 370°C. The TGA curve of 2 () reveals a weight loss of 7.31% from room temperature to 134°C, which can be assigned to the weight loss of the lattice water molecules (calcd=7.27%). The subsequent weight loss of 4.76% from 134°C to 343°C can be attributed to the weight loss of the coordinated water molecules (calcd=4.85%). And from 343°C the decomposition of the framework of 2 starts.

The temperature-dependent magnetic susceptibility data of 1 and 2 have been measured for polycrystalline samples at an applied magnetic field of 10 kOe in the temperature range of 2-300K, as shown in  . For 1, χm  is the molar magnetic susceptibility for per Ni2 unit (A ring in ). The experimental χmT value at room temperature is 2.45cm3 mol-1 K, which is as expected for two magnetically quasi-isolated S =1 ions (g >2.00). Upon cooling, the χmT value increases to a maximum of 3.12cm3 mol-1 K at 5.55K, following with a sharp decrease to 2.56cm3 mol-1 K at 2K, suggesting an overall ferromagnetic interaction. Fitting all data to the Curie-Weiss law gave Weiss constant of θ =3.42K (), also indicative of ferromagnetic exchange interactions. With the consideration of the intermolecular exchange interaction (ZJ') in the molecular-field approximation, the magnetic analysis was carried out by using the spin Hamiltonian   H = - 2   JS   1     S   2   - D (   S   1   2   +   S   2   2   )  , where J is the intramolecular exchange integral, D the zero-field splitting parameter. And the expression of magnetic susceptibility reported in the literature can be used to fit the data . A good fit was achieved with the fitting parameters as follows: g =2.204, J  = +2.70cm-1, D =-0.035cm-1, ZJ'=-0.133cm-1 and the agreement factor R =Σ[(χmT)obsd -(χmT)calcd]2/Σ(χmT)2 obsd is 1.28×10-4.

decomposition temperature.type: weight loss of lattice water molecules

metadata.title: Syntheses, topological analyses and magnetic properties of two 3D supramolecular nickel-organic frameworks constructed from 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylate and flexible imidazole-based ligands
